text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Twenty-two members of parliament demand the withdrawal of Nyanza provincial commissioner Joseph Kaguthi for undermining elected leadcers and dividing people among ethnic lines.
- Cardinal Maurice Otunga, archbishop of the Roman Catholic Church in Kenya, retires.
- The World Bank suspends funding to Kenya's health ministry until reforms are implemented.
- Two members of parliament give opposition Democratic Party leader Mwai Kibaki one month to call party presidential nomination elections.
- The government directs shipping companies to stop dealing with the suspended secretary general of the National Seamen's Union of Kenya.
- Nairobi University's engineering faculty is hit by an acute shortage of staff because of an exodus of lecturers.
- President Daniel arap Moi thanks the Italian government for assistance to Kenya.
- The Minister for Culture and Social Services Nyiva Mwendwa denies U.S. President Bill Clinton of the United States gave cash awards to Kenyans in the 1995 special Olympics.
- Airport authorities at Mombasa airport in Mombasa detain a Zaire-bound plane on suspicion it is smuggling fuel to the rebel-held eastern Zaire. ($1=54 Kenya Shillings)
